text: The cellular target of teixobactin is peptidoglycan synthesis in Gram-positive bacteria (the peptide cannot penetrate the Gram-negative outer membrane).
In this environmental “buddy system,” one species provides a growth factor to another species that cannot make its own.
To harvest previously unculturable soil microbes, samples prepared from soil were diluted such that one bacterial cell was delivered into each channel of a multichannel iChip microbe could grow.

The mechanism of domestication is not yet The scientists made extracts from 10,000 iChip isolates and tested each one for antibiotic activity against Staphylococcus aureus, an important pathogen that can cause infections ranging from boils to sepsis.
Both sides of the device were covered with semipermeable membranes and placed back into the of the unculturable microbes to form colonies.
The classic approach for finding new antibiotics is to screen bacteria and fungi snatched from exotic environments such as the Amazon for secreted antimicrobial compounds.
The structure of the antibiotic, teixobactin, is shown enzymes instead of a ribosome (nonribosomal peptide synthesis is described in Special Topic 15.1).
Scientists, for their part, have struggled to find new antibiotics to replace the old, ineffective ones.
The Gram-negative organism that produced this antibiotic was sequenced and named Eleftheria terrae (Fig. 2).
There is a quiet panic among infectious disease doctors, who worry that we will soon run out of effective antibiotics to treat deadly infections.

The new antibiotic kills bacteria by binding to the lipid carrier molecule, bactoprenol, that ferries the peptidoglycan subunits N-acetylglucosamine and N-acetylmuramic acid across the bacterial membrane (described in Chapter 3).
Once a colony formed, the previously uncultured organism became “domesticated,” able to grow on agar medium without further assistance.
Kim Lewis (Northeastern University, Boston) and colleagues have devised an elegant method to do just that.
Chapter 27 describes the details of peptidoglycan synthesis and the antibiotics that target steps in this process.
This method worked for decades, but over the past 20 years was needed if we humans are to maintain dominance over we can detect can be cultured in the laboratory.
This means we have missed capturing the antibiotic potential of over 99% of living microbes.
Since antibiotics were introduced over 70 years ago, bacterial pathogens have continually evolved to resist their effects.
As a result, growing cells lyse because they cannot make new cell wall.
One extract was highly effective.
Can we find a way to tame such uncooperative organisms and screen them for new antibiotics?
They grow in their natural environments because of interspecies cooperation.
Why do the microbes grow there but not in the lab?
These “unculturable” organisms are present in soil, water, and even the human body.
Chapter 27 will discuss this “arms race” in more detail.
